stream_context.summary: Kaze works inside the Overworld (main island) block-outs for parts 6 & 7, filling an empty stretch of land, assigning entrances for several planned "secret" mini-levels, and tweaking visual details in Fast64 while chatting about technical hurdles and future plans.

development_findings.summary: A private beta test of Course 6 ran smoothly, signalling that major gameplay bugs are resolved for that stage
Fast64 is the primary level-export tool used to push new geometry into the Mario 64 decompilation
development_findings.quote: This is Fast 64 – it lets me export my level into the Mario 64 decompilation.

development_findings.summary: RTYI temporarily failed on the popular Parallel Launcher emulator; Kaze co-fixed the bug with the maintainer a week before the demo, but the patched plugin never shipped, leaving many players unable to run the build
development_findings.quote: A week before the RTYI demo released I fixed it with the guy that maintains Parallel Launcher and then the update didn't get pushed out.

development_findings.summary: The Overworld had a visually dull, empty stretch; solution is to embed a coin-gated ‘athlete Yoshi’ who, after three sponsorship payments, launches Mario into the Rainbow Slide level where you race him for a star
Kaze is adding a family of single-mechanic mini-levels (Cloud-Cap, Wing-Cap, Rainbow Slide, Minecart, Pinball, Shy Guy Hide-and-Seek, Pick-Your-Power Fruits). Each is scoped to ‘half a day’ to build
development_findings.quote: All of these are like half-a-day levels… they’ll add so much to the game.

development_findings.summary: He plans a UI change: the map screen should display how many stars remain in each Overworld region
The current Mario model still needs final tweaks (e.g., cap-bounce animation and specific shadow effects) before being locked forever
development_findings.quote: I was about to finalize Mario’s model too… add back his cap falling up and down when he jumps.

development_findings.summary: Coin economy is under active design; Kaze debates lots of small coin gates vs one large ‘coin dump’ such as a wishing well to avoid forced grinding
Sauraen is composing a fully dynamic soundtrack for the retro section, inspired by Breath of the Wild’s adaptive music
Kaze intends to announce the annual F3 showcase (his personal ‘E3’) around 19 July and is weighing up taking a commercial sponsor for the first time

context_findings.summary: RTYI will likely be a cash loss if YouTube and Patreon income are treated as separate; long-term business decisions hinge on how well RTYI performs
context_findings.quote: If you assume my Patreon exists for my YouTube videos rather than RTYI, it’s going to be a net negative.

context_findings.summary: Nintendo has removed 71 of Kaze’s YouTube videos; he believes Nintendo targets videos rather than IPS patches to avoid setting legal precedents
context_findings.quote: They don’t even take down the mods… they only come after videos which to me feels extremely petty.

context_findings.summary: Kaze openly dreams of founding a studio that ships both original games and parallel ROM-hacks if RTYI made ‘20 million dollars’
context_findings.quote: If I make 20 million dollars off RTYI, I’m opening a game studio… develop real games that were also fan games at the same time.

context_findings.summary: He values design feedback from peers regardless of status (e.g., he would show the project to Shigeru Miyamoto purely for design critique)
Personal slice-of-life moments: two 300-litre fish tanks; playful banter with Zeina; classical music ‘driving him insane’
Displays scepticism toward online discourse, AI-generated content, and ‘manufactured consensus’
context_findings.quote: Everything’s fake… needs to sound right.

context_findings.summary: Considering putting F3 under sponsorship to monetise his showcase for the first time

biobak.summary: Will be paid from project funds; pops in to discuss pinball memories and compliments grass texture work
biobak.quote: Shout-outs to Biobak for liking my grass.

zeina.summary: Zeina appears briefly (feeding their child, phone buzzing), offers minor comments (e.g., ‘move an Android’); illustrates casual home-office dynamic

key_stories.title: Parallel Launcher Fiasco
key_stories.summary: Days before the public demo, Kaze and the Parallel Launcher maintainer fixed critical emulator bugs. Because the patched plugin never shipped, most players still crashed, souring the launch.
key_stories.challenge: RTYI would not boot on the community’s most-used emulator.
key_stories.process: Kaze collaborated directly with the emulator maintainer and produced a fix.
key_stories.outcome: Patch stayed unreleased; only a few users who manually updated could play.
key_stories.key_quote: A week before the RTYI demo released I fixed it… and then the update didn't get pushed out.

key_stories.title: Nintendo’s Takedown Pattern
key_stories.summary: Nintendo has flagged 71 of Kaze’s videos, repeatedly wiping million-view uploads. Patches remain untouched, reinforcing his belief that Nintendo avoids legal risk while still stifling visibility.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining public presence while legally vulnerable content is removed.
key_stories.process: Kaze contests strikes where possible; accepts that many remain offline.
key_stories.outcome: Permanent loss of reach and revenue; heightened wariness but continued development.
key_stories.key_quote: Every time a video hit a million views they took it down.

key_stories.title: Filling the Empty Overworld Strip
key_stories.summary: An uninspiring stretch of terrain in Part 6 prompted an in-stream design jam. Kaze invents the ‘athlete Yoshi’ sponsorship mechanic that simultaneously fixes level pacing and introduces the Rainbow Slide secret.
key_stories.challenge: A long, boring stretch of land between two points.
key_stories.process: Live brainstorming of coin-gated events and level hooks with chat feedback.
key_stories.outcome: New plan: pay a training Yoshi three times; he then catapults Mario into a Rainbow Slide race level.
key_stories.key_quote: After you sponsor him three times, he’s yoked… and they jump into the fucking moon.

open_questions.context: Multiple minor coin gates (athlete Yoshi, hint Yoshis, purchasable beans) are planned, but Kaze worries about forced grinding versus one large sink.
questions: What is the final design philosophy for coins?
Will there be a single major coin dump or several small gates?
How do you balance grind avoidance with rewarding exploration?

open_questions.context: Many quick ‘half-day’ levels were added (Cloud-Cap, Wing-Cap, Pinball, etc.).
questions: Have those levels been fully green-lit or are any still tentative?
How will you ensure they don’t bloat testing and art workloads?
Which contributor owns each of these minis?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants to freeze the player model ‘forever’ after cap-bounce tweaks.
questions: What’s left to change on Mario?
Who signs off on final character rig/animations?
Could late tweaks cascade into other assets or code?

open_questions.context: Kaze is debating taking a sponsor for his annual showcase.
questions: What criteria will decide if F3 gets a sponsor?
How would sponsorship revenue feed back into RTYI?
Are there ethical or creative constraints on potential sponsors?
Do you have a contingency if Nintendo escalates beyond YouTube takedowns?
Would you ever re-brand or fully de-Mario future hacks?
Is there legal counsel involved now?

open_questions.context: Parallel Launcher patch never shipped; future recompilation may target multiple platforms.
questions: How will you guarantee day-one compatibility across emulators and real hardware?
Is static recompilation to GameCube/Wii still a goal?
Who owns ongoing maintenance of third-party emulator fixes?
